text: hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the
Internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for review the new valentin fire
record splinters this is the sophomore
full-length LP from the uk-based metal
outfit valent fire they're seen as a bit
of an underground supergroup considering
that the band's frontman and guitarist
Gregor Mackintosh played guitar in
Paradise Lost band member Hamish Glen
cross also played guitar in my dying
bride as well as the band solstice and
the band's drummer Adrian Erland sand
also played in Paradise Lost as well as
Cradle of Filth and many other bands too
now I first came across these guys in
2011 when they dropped their full-length
debut album titled
a fragile King it was an album that
combined the the slow and heavy sounds
of doom metal with the abrasiveness of
death metal sonic Lee it was a little
standard for death doom but the subject
matter of these tracks were really what
caught my attention a lot of the tracks
lyrically on this album dived into the
personal suffering felt by Gregor
Mackintosh after losing his father to
lung cancer in 2009 and the lyrics go
about addressing this addressing this
pain addressing this loss in a kind of
poetic way which was a pretty moving and
emotional and interesting angle for a
death metal record but there were a lot
of very slow dreary deep cuts on this LP
that just didn't really connect with me
but still the performances on this
record were good it seemed that the band
put value on production value with just
how massive and atmospheric a lot of
these songs sounded and while I wasn't
really familiar with Gregor singing
abilities prior to the release of this
record he seemed like he had the makings
of becoming a really monstrous death
metal vocalist and then I heard Kurt
Beaulieu of converge was doing
production on this thing who you may or
may not know is is really probably my
favorite producer right now however I
did not just fall in love with the sound
of this Valon fire record as fantastic
as it is with all these very clear
punchy pummeling drums blood cape
guitars vocals sit in a really perfect
spot in the mix oh that's great but it's
really the fact that these guys came
through with a more diverse record this
time
that really had me listening to this
thing from beginning and end and and
liking it however I'm not really sure if
this change of pace is going to please
death doom fans or even hardcore death
metal fans people who have been
following the band up until this point
I mean valent fire still comes through
stillbirths some really slow monolithic
devilish death doom on a few tracks here
they even managed to embrace a little
bit of melody on these tracks but I
would expect nothing less from a band
related to my dying bride however mixed
in with this handful of songs Vallon
fire puts in some really fast paced
songs to some really violent songs these
guys seem to be embracing sort of a
death and roll aesthetic like you would
get with the bands such as entombed but
I actually think going that far back
isn't as accurate a comparison as a more
recent band that does death and roll
like black breath
who Kurt Beaulieu actually did
production for as well like the 1 minute
and 27 second song instinct slaughter
which is speedy its relentless its
ferocious and heavy it's got kind of a
punk attitude and doesn't sound too
unlike band like nails with on silent
death at least in the guitars so to some
people especially hardcore death metal
fans who like these various strains of
the genre to not bleed into one another
too much this LP might sound like kind
of a mixed bag but personally for me the
guitar tone does the sound of the drums
and the vocals are enough to create a
common thread that runs throughout all
these tracks plus I'm sort of into the
idea that this depressing cloud that the
band was formed under on their debut
album is dissipating or - sort of moving
away a little bit freeing the band up to
explore more aggressive material because
there are certainly tracks on this LP
that transition from these slow do me
guitar passages to something more
hardcore and overtly aggressive despite
that I have to say I don't think
splinters is going to be the most bold
and refreshing death metal album you
hear this year but I do think it brings
together a very good mix of tracks that
are incredibly visceral or very bleak
and depressing in their slow pace and
heaviness the most stunning of which is
the song breath
the longest track here it features all
these melodic guitar leads some of which
are harmonized with one another that are
woven into these monolithic riffs riffs
that are encased in to this buzzsaw
Distortion and lyrically I'm catching a
lot of the same loss and and religious
themes that I was hearing on a fragile
King and they still work pretty well
here the title track is another example
of these do mere flavours executed in a
really great way and from here it just
seems that the band gets faster and
heavier and more aggressive but it's not
like the band is playing doom and
they're playing fast paced death and
roll there's a bit of a gradient here
and on the most intense side of this
gradient these more fast paced
aggressive songs can occasionally be a
little hit or miss like the hyper
aggressive instinct slaughter that I
mentioned earlier this track and other
songs on here that tend to land around
the two-minute mark while Vallon fire is
perfectly capable of playing this fast
and playing this aggressively there's
not much about the sound of their
instrumentation or their riffs that
really sticks out it really feels like
they're just going through the motions
on tracks like this even after they put
them immediately after some of the
slower songs on this record as if
they're creating this really breakneck
change by putting the slowest track here
next to the fastest and shortest track
when I mean really in reality it's all
loud as hell and super crimey and
aggressive so it's not like the the
change is that great there are some more
aggressive tracks on here that manage to
pack in a little bit of melodic finesse
though like scabs the opener on here
which has this interesting little for
note I believe guitar lead that really
brings a somber tone to these riffs
which are really slow intense and heavy
at the start of the song but then the
band immediately breaks into something
speedier and more intense I also love
the wailing guitar leads that call and
respond with the vocals on the track
savages arise there's a killer breakdown
on the second half that I love and the
band manages to bring a lot of very
surprising changes and just twists and
turns into this two minute and forty
second one time on this track there are
a lot of just riff and performance
highlights throughout this
album and that's because at the end of
the day even if you are underwhelmed by
valent fires lack of originality
they are a well-greased death machine
with fantastic production good songs and
good riffs most of the time their
approach might be a little too simple to
blow anybody away especially a seasoned
death metal fan but I personally value
the fact that whenever I listen to this
thing I'm having a pretty strong
physical response to it yes at the end
of the day I do really want more from
this band lyrically and compositionally
but I still think that if you're looking
for some death metal that's gonna hit
hard and be thrilling be exciting
be aggressive then there's no reason not
to look into this LP I'm feeling strong
6 to a light 7 on this transition if
you've given this record to listen what
did you think of it did you love it did
you hate it why what do you think I
should review next and that's it anthony
Fantino forever
